Are you interested in the performance data along with engine specifications? Then you are at the right time and place! Here we share the top trade secrets about starting modes and how acceleration 0 to 60 times works in particular…

You probably may have known that the run-up time depends on the type of fuel and tires, extra weight, road conditions and many other essential factors. So, which of them affects your car acceleration rate?

How Does It Work?

Measuring the vehicle’s 0-60 speed is usually done in some enclosed area by professional drivers. Each variable – wind, weather, or traction – can have a dramatic impact on the overall acceleration time recorded. The crew connects precise measuring tools (Doppler radar guns & precise timing instruments) to computers, and the test-driver is not worried about the exact moment of hitting 60 miles per hour.

His task is to focus solely on driving fast and straight. The car is timed going in 2 separate and opposite directions; and these 2 times are averaged together for the commonly accepted 0-60 figure. Typically, automobile magazines post the run-up time achieved in such testing. Indeed, acceleration time is a very useful indicator of the car power, if it’s been reported by a reputable source.

0-60 Times in Real Life:

7 Trade Secrets to Know about Acceleration Numbers

  1. 0-60 times is a performance measure commonly used for automotive acceleration from 0 to 60 mph, from 0 to 97 km/h, or from 0 to 27 m/s either in the United States or in the United Kingdom. The rest of the world uses 0 to 100 km/h, which corresponds to 0 to 62.5 mph.
  2. In fact, less than 1% of all 0-60 mph time numbers determines auto stats. In 99% cases, 0-60 times will be converted to 0-62 acceleration data. Please note this fact!
  3. Most people do not understand that run-up time is determined by a number of automotive authorities from all over the world. Still, these indicators have never been an object of absolute science. On the one hand, a particular tested car may arrive at a different result, despite the fact that all the variables have been kept the same in each acceleration test. On the other hand, a classic car, luxury car, sports car, muscle car, hybrid car, exotic car or whatever it may be is almost certain to demonstrate a different 0 to 60 result too, because the acceleration test is not performed with exact same variables.
  4. As you can see, each 0 to 60 mph test will be significantly different for each source. What’s more, non-professional tests conducted by amateur car drivers are the most inaccurate, in fact. The collective philosophy of auto gurus is to provide a range of acceptable, rather than popular finite run-up time results. For example, the acceleration rate should be listed as 3.2, 3.6… to 4.0, 4.2… seconds – it’s the best way to balance all the amateur and professional tests for each vehicle.
  5. Present performance cars achieve their 0 to 60 mph in less than 6 seconds, whereas exotic cars accelerate in between 3 and 4 seconds. Currently, the fastest production street car is Bugatti Veyron Super Sport that reaches 60 mph from a stop in 2.46 seconds!
  6. Your own automobile may show different performance data, compared with absolute measurements. Keep in mind that a number of factors are to be considered when analyzing 0 to 60 stats. They include but are not limited to the following: vehicle tuning, type of driver, amount of fuel, race track surface condition, barometric pressure, engine & outside air temperature, etc. Typically, an average of the best 2 runs in each direction (so as to eliminate the wind factor) determines the final estimate of 0 to 60 times. A reliable resource means that acceleration data should work unless there are technological improvements like transmission enhancements, power output, and AWD system, affecting the performance specs of cars.
  7. With new vehicles appearing here and there, 0-60 time estimation may turn out quite far from actual auto specs. Please, keep in mind that some car companies regulate their data later. In most cases, 0-60 times figures improve each year for particular car models. However, vehicle’s performance can go down as well, due to more “bells and whistles” instead of engine enhancements.

Our team is truly passionate about cars, particularly when it comes to 0 to 60 times! We keep adding new and hard-to-find 0-60 times and 1/4 mile of all possible car models. So, please, have our automotive website bookmarked as a useful resource for many car enthusiasts!
